content:
terrible testcases, missing the important cases starting or passing through 7

this lets solutions that incorrectly terminate at length 1 pass when they shouldn't

The "Big Number" test is exceed the limit "10^20" ...
 99999999999999999999999999999999
here are 32 repeat 9

Good problem.

Hard to get the reader to really understand what it's about. (The final paragraph doesn't help at all--I'd drop it if I were you)

Maybe put a bit more plain english before the math? Something like "A number is called happy when repeatedly summing the square of its digits yields 1"

As a side note, this ends up with code a bit more complex than I'm used to in 5-minute clashes, but that's not necessarily a problem.

s(404) contains 1? It's not clear, because
s(404) = 4^2+0^2+4^2=16+0+16=32
I complete the brief. You have to check the sequence  s(404), s(32), s(13), s(10) until number one appears or not

Thanks for your help, JBM.
This way ?...
You think 10 minutes is needed ?

About the text: obviously I like the intro better, but now it's a bit light math-wise. You ought to at least leave an example derivation or two. Like, say, one that ends in 1 and one that doesn't.

About the length, I think it's feasible to do in 5, but I'm biased. A more objective observation is that it's harder than the average 5-minute problem currently in the pool. Not sure how it fares wrt the current 10-minutes problems, I haven't done any in quite some time.
